newsitem.title: INDONESIA: S.E. Asian cocoa producers mull common contract.
newsitem.headline: S.E. Asian cocoa producers mull common contract.

text.p: Southeast Asian cocoa producers opened a two-day meeting on Tuesday to explore setting up a regional trading contract to reduce dependence on foreign pacts.
Conference delegates said there was a long way to go before the contract, covering the seven members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), could be realised, however.
"We want to make an inventory of the very important factors for this contract," conference chairman Suharyo Husen of Indonesia's Agriculture Ministry told Reuters.
"The contract will be in the interest of all ASEAN members. We wantra-ASEAN business (in cocoa).
Delegates said an ASEAN contract would offer other advantages such as providing dispute-solving mechanisms within the region.
"The problem now is whether the contract we want to set up will gain the confidence of the international cocoa community," Siswoputranto said. "That's the key."
Indonesia, the world's third largest cocoa producer after the Ivory Coast and Ghana, has been forecast to produce between 319,000 and 330,000 tonnes in 1997, up 10 percent from 1996.
Malaysia's 1997 output is expected to remain unchanged at its 1996 level of 125,00 tonnes.
